articles.title: An interstellar visitor lights up the Red Planet’s sky
articles.summary: ESA’s Mars orbiters have observed comet 3I/ATLAS, only the third interstellar comet ever discovered. The faint, distant object revealed a glowing coma as it was heated by the Sun. Researchers are still studying the data to understand its makeup and origins. This rare event also foreshadows future missions like the Comet Interceptor, designed to chase such elusive visitors.
articles.content:
Between October 1 and 7, ESA's ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter (TGO) and Mars Express spacecraft turned their instruments toward interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS as it passed near Mars.

Of all ESA spacecraft, the two Mars orbiters had the best view of this rare visitor. During its closest approach to the Red Planet on October 3, the comet was about 30 million km away.

Both orbiters used their onboard cameras to track the comet's motion. These instruments are typically designed to capture Mars's bright surface from just a few hundred to a few thousand kilometers above it, so observing such a faint object at such a great distance presented a major challenge.

ExoMars TGO successfully recorded a series of images using its Colour and Stereo Surface Imaging System (CaSSIS). In the animation below, comet 3I/ATLAS appears as a faint white spot drifting downward near the center. That small blur marks the heart of the comet, made up of its icy, rocky nucleus surrounded by a glowing cloud called the coma.

Because the comet was so distant, CaSSIS could not separate the nucleus from the coma. Detecting the nucleus itself would have been like trying to spot a mobile phone on the Moon from Earth.

The coma, however, is clearly visible. Stretching several thousand kilometers across, it forms as sunlight warms the comet, releasing gas and dust that collect into a hazy halo around the core.

CaSSIS could not measure the coma's full extent because its brightness fades rapidly with distance from the nucleus, eventually disappearing into background noise.

Usually, gas and dust from the coma stream away to create a long tail that can stretch for millions of kilometers as the comet nears the Sun. The tail is much dimmer than the coma, so it does not appear in the current images, but it could become visible in future observations as 3I/ATLAS heats up and sheds more ice.

Nick Thomas, Principal Investigator of the CaSSIS camera, said, "This was a very challenging observation for the instrument. The comet is around 10,000 to 100,000 times fainter than our usual target.

The work continues

So far, 3I/ATLAS has not been detected in the Mars Express images. One reason is that Mars Express can only take exposures of up to 0.5 seconds (its maximum limit), while ExoMars TGO was able to use five-second exposures.

Researchers are continuing to process the data from both orbiters. They plan to combine multiple Mars Express images to enhance the faint signal and improve their chances of detecting the comet.

The teams also attempted to study the comet's light spectrum using the OMEGA and SPICAM spectrometers on Mars Express and the NOMAD instrument on ExoMars TGO. It remains uncertain whether the coma and tail were bright enough to allow scientists to identify the comet's chemical composition.

Over the coming weeks and months, researchers will keep analyzing the data to learn more about the materials that make up 3I/ATLAS and how it changes as it draws closer to the Sun.

Colin Wilson, Mars Express and ExoMars project scientist at ESA, said: "Though our Mars orbiters continue to make impressive contributions to Mars science, it's always extra exciting to see them responding to unexpected situations like this one. I look forward to seeing what the data reveals following further analysis."

A rare visitor

Originating from outside our Solar System, comet 3I/ATLAS is only the third interstellar comet ever seen, following 1I/ʻOumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019.

These comets are absolutely foreign. Every planet, moon, asteroid, comet and lifeform in our Solar System share a common origin. But interstellar comets are true outsiders, carrying clues about the formation of worlds far beyond our own.

Comet 3I/ATLAS was first spotted on July 1, 2025, by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System (ATLAS) telescope in Río Hurtado, Chile. Since then, astronomers have used ground-based and space telescopes to monitor its progress and discover more about it.

Based on its trajectory, astronomers suspect that 3I/ATLAS could be the oldest comet ever observed. It may be three billion years older than the Solar System, which is itself already 4.6 billion years old.

What's next?

Next month, we will observe the comet with our Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice). Though Juice will be further from 3I/ATLAS than our Mars orbiters were last week, it will see the comet just after its closest approach to the Sun, meaning that it will be in a more active state. We don't expect to receive data from Juice's observations until February 2026 -- find out why in our FAQs.

Icy wanderers such as 3I/ATLAS offer a rare, tangible connection to the broader galaxy. To actually visit one would connect humankind with the Universe on a far greater scale. To this end, ESA is preparing the Comet Interceptor mission.

Comet Interceptor is due to launch in 2029 into a parking orbit, from where it will lie in wait for a suitable target -- a pristine comet from the distant Oort Cloud that surrounds our Solar System, or, unlikely but highly appealing, an interstellar object like 3I/ATLAS.

Michael Kueppers, Comet Interceptor project scientist expands: "When Comet Interceptor was selected in 2019, we only knew of one interstellar object -- 1I/ʻOumuamua, discovered in 2017. Since then, two more such objects have been discovered, showing large diversity in their appearance. Visiting one could provide a breakthrough in understanding their nature."

While it remains improbable that we will discover an interstellar object that is reachable for Comet Interceptor, as a first demonstration of a rapid response mission that waits in space for its target, it will be a pathfinder for possible future missions to intercept these mysterious visitors.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a rare and significant scientific event: the observation of an interstellar comet by ESA's Mars orbiters, providing valuable data for understanding objects from beyond our Solar System. This has broad scientific significance and inspires curiosity about the universe, with detailed context and implications for future missions like the Comet Interceptor.
articles.personality_title: ESA’s Mars orbiters spot rare interstellar comet near Mars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study comets to learn about objects from space beyond our Solar System. Interstellar comets come from outside our Solar System and are very rare. Only two have been seen before 3I/ATLAS.

**What happened** – In early October 2025, ESA’s two Mars orbiters, the ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter and Mars Express, observed the comet 3I/ATLAS as it passed close to Mars. The comet was about 30 million kilometers away at its closest point. The orbiters used special cameras to capture images of the comet’s glowing coma, a cloud of gas and dust around its icy core.

**Impact** – This event is rare because interstellar comets are hard to spot and study. The data collected helps scientists understand what these comets are made of and where they come from. This comet might even be older than our Solar System. These observations also help prepare for future missions, like ESA’s Comet Interceptor, which will try to visit comets and other objects from far away.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will keep analyzing the images and data from the Mars orbiters. Soon, ESA’s Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice) will observe the comet again after it passes closest to the Sun. In 2029, the Comet Interceptor mission will launch to catch a comet or interstellar object, aiming to learn more about these mysterious visitors.

**One-sentence takeaway** – ESA’s Mars orbiters captured rare images of the interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, offering new clues about objects from beyond our Solar System and guiding future space missions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les orbiteurs martiens de l’ESA observent une comète interstellaire rare près de Mars
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les comètes pour en apprendre davantage sur des objets venus de l’espace au-delà de notre Système solaire. Les comètes interstellaires viennent de l’extérieur de notre Système solaire et sont très rares. Seules deux avaient été observées avant 3I/ATLAS.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Début octobre 2025, les deux orbiteurs martiens de l’ESA, l’ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter et Mars Express, ont observé la comète 3I/ATLAS alors qu’elle passait près de Mars. La comète se trouvait à environ 30 millions de kilomètres au point le plus proche. Les orbiteurs ont utilisé des caméras spéciales pour capturer des images de la coma brillante de la comète, un nuage de gaz et de poussière autour de son noyau glacé.

**Impact** – Cet événement est rare car les comètes interstellaires sont difficiles à repérer et à étudier. Les données collectées aident les scientifiques à comprendre la composition de ces comètes et leur origine. Cette comète pourrait même être plus vieille que notre Système solaire. Ces observations préparent aussi les futures missions, comme l’Intercepteur de Comète de l’ESA, qui tentera de visiter des comètes et autres objets lointains.

Bientôt, l’explorateur des lunes glacées de Jupiter (Juice) de l’ESA observera à nouveau la comète après son passage au plus près du Soleil. **Résumé en une phrase** – Les orbiteurs martiens de l’ESA ont capturé des images rares de la comète interstellaire 3I/ATLAS, offrant de nouvelles pistes sur les objets venus de l’extérieur de notre Système solaire et guidant les futures missions spatiales.
articles.personality_title_es: Los orbitadores marcianos de la ESA captan un raro cometa interestelar cerca de Marte
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian cometas para aprender sobre objetos del espacio que vienen de fuera de nuestro Sistema Solar. Los cometas interestelares vienen de fuera de nuestro Sistema Solar y son muy raros. Solo se habían visto dos antes de 3I/ATLAS.

**Qué pasó** – A principios de octubre de 2025, los dos orbitadores marcianos de la ESA, el ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter y Mars Express, observaron el cometa 3I/ATLAS cuando pasó cerca de Marte. El cometa estaba a unos 30 millones de kilómetros en su punto más cercano. Los orbitadores usaron cámaras especiales para capturar imágenes de la coma brillante del cometa, una nube de gas y polvo alrededor de su núcleo helado.

**Impacto** – Este evento es raro porque los cometas interestelares son difíciles de ver y estudiar. Los datos recogidos ayudan a los científicos a entender de qué están hechos estos cometas y de dónde vienen. Este cometa podría ser incluso más viejo que nuestro Sistema Solar. Estas observaciones también ayudan a preparar futuras misiones, como el Interceptor de Cometas de la ESA, que intentará visitar cometas y otros objetos lejanos.

**Frase clave** – Los orbitadores marcianos de la ESA captaron imágenes raras del cometa interestelar 3I/ATLAS, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre objetos de fuera de nuestro Sistema Solar y guiando futuras misiones espaciales.

articles.title: Closest alien civilization could be 33,000 light years away
articles.summary: Complex, intelligent life in the galaxy appears vanishingly rare, with the nearest possible civilization perhaps 33,000 light-years distant. Yet despite the odds, scientists insist that continuing the search for extraterrestrial intelligence is essential — for either outcome reshapes our understanding of life itself.
articles.content:
According to new research presented at the EPSC-DPS2025 Joint Meeting in Helsinki, the nearest technological civilization in the Milky Way could be roughly 33,000 light years away. For such a civilization to exist at the same time as humanity, it would need to have lasted for at least 280,000 years -- and potentially millions of years.

These findings highlight the overwhelming odds against discovering Earth-like planets that possess both plate tectonics and a nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere containing the right balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Taking these planetary requirements into account, the chances of success for SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) appear slim, say Dr. Manuel Scherf and Professor Helmut Lammer of the Space Research Institute at the Austrian Academy of Sciences in Graz.

"Extraterrestrial intelligences, ETIs, in our galaxy are probably pretty rare," says Scherf.

A planet's carbon dioxide level plays a key role in sustaining life. Higher levels of CO₂ help maintain photosynthesis and keep the atmosphere from leaking into space, but too much can trigger a runaway greenhouse effect or make the air toxic. Plate tectonics are essential because they regulate carbon dioxide through the carbon-silicate cycle, recycling the gas between the atmosphere and the planet's crust. Over time, however, carbon dioxide becomes trapped in rocks and is no longer returned to the atmosphere.

"At some point enough carbon dioxide will be drawn from the atmosphere so that photosynthesis will stop working," says Scherf. "For the Earth, that's expected to happen in about 200 million to roughly one billion years."

Today, Earth's atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen (78 percent) and oxygen (21 percent), with only a trace of carbon dioxide (0.042 percent). Scherf and Lammer modeled what would happen on other worlds. A planet with ten percent carbon dioxide -- if located farther from its sun or orbiting a dimmer, younger star -- could support a biosphere for up to 4.2 billion years. By comparison, a planet with one percent carbon dioxide would remain habitable for about 3.1 billion years.

For advanced life to emerge, such planets would also need at least 18 percent oxygen. Complex animals require higher oxygen levels, and earlier studies have shown that if oxygen drops below this threshold, there would not be enough free oxygen for open-air combustion. Without fire, metalworking would be impossible, preventing the rise of any technological civilization.

Scherf and Lammer compared these potential biosphere lifetimes with how long it took life on Earth to evolve technology -- about 4.5 billion years -- and with the expected longevity of intelligent species. The longer a civilization endures, the higher the likelihood that it overlaps in time with another.

From these calculations, the researchers concluded that a technological species on a planet with ten percent carbon dioxide would need to persist for at least 280,000 years for even one other civilization to exist in the Milky Way at the same time as ours.

"For ten civilizations to exist at the same time as ours, the average lifetime must be above 10 million years," says Scherf. "The numbers of ETIs are pretty low and depend strongly upon the lifetime of a civilization."

This means that if we do detect an ETI, it is almost certainly going to be much older than humanity.

It's these numbers that also lead to the estimate that the next closest technological civilization is about 33,000 light years away. Our Sun is about 27,000 light years from the galactic center, which means that the next closest technological civilization to our own could be on the other side of the Milky Way.

These numbers are not absolutes - Scherf points out that there are other factors that should be included, such as the origin of life, the origin of photosynthesis, the origin of multi-cellular life and the frequency with which intelligent life develops technology, but they cannot be quantified at present. If each of these factors has a high probability, then ETIs might not be as rare. If each of these factors has a low probability, then a more pessimistic outlook is required.

Nevertheless, Scherf strongly believes that SETI should continue the search.

"Although ETIs might be rare there is only one way to really find out and that is by searching for it," says Scherf. "If these searches find nothing, it makes our theory more likely, and if SETI does find something, then it will be one of the biggest scientific breakthroughs ever achieved as we would know that we are not alone in the Universe."
articles.reasoning: The article reports on new scientific research that advances our understanding of the rarity and distribution of intelligent extraterrestrial life in the Milky Way. It highlights the challenges and scientific criteria for life-supporting planets and emphasizes the importance of continuing the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). This represents a significant scientific endeavor with broad implications for humanity's understanding of life in the universe, inspiring curiosity and hope about future discoveries.
articles.personality_title: New study estimates nearest alien civilization could be 33,000 light years away
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long searched for signs of intelligent life beyond Earth, but finding other civilizations depends on many factors like the right planet conditions and how long those civilizations last.

**What happened** – Researchers from the Austrian Academy of Sciences shared new findings at a space science meeting in Helsinki. They calculated that the closest advanced alien civilization in our Milky Way galaxy might be about 33,000 light years away. For such a civilization to exist now, it would have to survive for at least 280,000 years. The study looked at planet features like having plate tectonics and just the right amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide to support complex life.

**Impact** – This research shows that planets able to support intelligent life are very rare and that civilizations need to last a very long time to overlap with ours. For example, planets need enough oxygen (at least 18%) for animals and technology like metalworking to develop. Also, carbon dioxide levels must be balanced to keep life going without becoming harmful. Because of these strict conditions, the chances of finding another civilization close to us are low. But if we do find one, it would be a huge discovery.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to keep searching for extraterrestrial intelligence using new technologies and methods. Even if no aliens are found soon, the search helps improve our theories about life in space. Future research may also include more factors, like how life starts or how often technology develops, to better estimate where and when alien civilizations might exist.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The closest alien civilization might be very far away, but carefully studying planet conditions helps guide ongoing searches for intelligent life beyond Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude estime que la civilisation extraterrestre la plus proche pourrait se trouver à 33 000 années-lumière
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques cherchent depuis longtemps des signes de vie intelligente au-delà de la Terre, mais trouver d'autres civilisations dépend de nombreux facteurs comme les bonnes conditions planétaires et la durée de vie de ces civilisations.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l'Académie autrichienne des sciences ont présenté de nouvelles découvertes lors d'une réunion scientifique à Helsinki. Ils ont calculé que la civilisation extraterrestre avancée la plus proche dans notre galaxie, la Voie lactée, pourrait se situer à environ 33 000 années-lumière. Pour qu'une telle civilisation existe aujourd'hui, elle devrait survivre au moins 280 000 ans. L'étude a examiné des caractéristiques planétaires comme la tectonique des plaques et la bonne quantité d'oxygène et de dioxyde de carbone nécessaires à la vie complexe.

**Impact** – Cette recherche montre que les planètes capables de soutenir la vie intelligente sont très rares et que les civilisations doivent durer très longtemps pour coexister avec la nôtre. Par exemple, les planètes doivent avoir assez d'oxygène (au moins 18 %) pour que les animaux et la technologie comme la métallurgie puissent se développer. Aussi, le dioxyde de carbone doit être équilibré pour maintenir la vie sans devenir toxique. À cause de ces conditions strictes, les chances de trouver une autre civilisation proche sont faibles. Mais si nous en trouvons une, ce serait une découverte majeure.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques prévoient de continuer à chercher une intelligence extraterrestre avec de nouvelles technologies et méthodes. Même si aucun alien n'est trouvé rapidement, la recherche améliore nos théories sur la vie dans l'espace. Les futures études pourraient aussi inclure plus de facteurs, comme l'origine de la vie ou la fréquence du développement technologique, pour mieux estimer où et quand les civilisations extraterrestres pourraient exister.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La civilisation extraterrestre la plus proche pourrait être très éloignée, mais l'étude des conditions planétaires aide à orienter les recherches d'une vie intelligente au-delà de la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio estima que la civilización alienígena más cercana podría estar a 33,000 años luz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han buscado durante mucho tiempo señales de vida inteligente fuera de la Tierra, pero encontrar otras civilizaciones depende de muchos factores, como las condiciones adecuadas del planeta y cuánto tiempo duran esas civilizaciones.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Academia de Ciencias de Austria presentaron nuevos hallazgos en una reunión científica en Helsinki. Calcularon que la civilización alienígena avanzada más cercana en nuestra galaxia, la Vía Láctea, podría estar a unos 33,000 años luz. Para que esa civilización exista ahora, tendría que sobrevivir al menos 280,000 años. El estudio analizó características planetarias como la tectónica de placas y la cantidad justa de oxígeno y dióxido de carbono para sostener vida compleja.

**Impacto** – Esta investigación muestra que los planetas capaces de sostener vida inteligente son muy raros y que las civilizaciones deben durar mucho tiempo para coincidir con la nuestra. Por ejemplo, los planetas necesitan al menos un 18 % de oxígeno para que los animales y tecnologías como la metalurgia se desarrollen. Además, los niveles de dióxido de carbono deben estar equilibrados para mantener la vida sin ser tóxicos. Debido a estas condiciones estrictas, las probabilidades de encontrar otra civilización cerca son bajas. Pero si la encontramos, sería un gran descubrimiento.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean seguir buscando inteligencia extraterrestre usando nuevas tecnologías y métodos. Aunque no se encuentren aliens pronto, la búsqueda ayuda a mejorar nuestras teorías sobre la vida en el espacio. Las futuras investigaciones también podrían incluir más factores, como el origen de la vida o la frecuencia con que se desarrolla la tecnología, para estimar mejor dónde y cuándo podrían existir civilizaciones alienígenas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La civilización alienígena más cercana podría estar muy lejos, pero estudiar las condiciones planetarias ayuda a guiar la búsqueda de vida inteligente más allá de la Tierra.
